intro: Neophloga curtisii, commonly known as the Curtis's mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of host trees, primarily in tropical and subtropical regions. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and has a distinctive appearance with small, leathery leaves and clusters of white or pale yellow flowers. The plant produces small, fleshy berries that are a source of food for various bird species. Neophloga curtisii relies on its host for water and nutrients, while still performing some photosynthesis. Its unique ecological role makes it an important component of forest ecosystems.
